questions.prompt: In BG 4.1, what does Krishna reveal about the origin of yoga?
choices: It was invented by ancient sages primarily
It was taught by Him to the sun god
It is found primarily in sacred books
It was developed gradually over many ages
questions.feedback: Krishna taught this yoga to Vivasvan (sun god) at the creation of the universe.

questions.prompt: Why does BG 4.2 warn that spiritual knowledge becomes lost over time?
choices: The rationalist error that texts alone preserve understanding permanently
Succession breaks when unqualified teach without realization
The progressivist belief that knowledge naturally improves with time
Material degradation automatically destroys all spiritual wisdom
questions.feedback: Knowledge transmitted through living disciplic succession degrades when links break-unqualified teachers distort teachings they haven't realized, necessitating periodic renewal by Krishna Himself.

questions.prompt: What does BG 4.5 reveal about why few recognize Krishna's divinity despite His regular appearances?
choices: The agnostic position that divinity cannot be known with certainty
Material conditioning obscures transcendental perception
The atheist claim that no divine persons exist to recognize
Krishna appears too rarely for people to become familiar with Him
questions.feedback: Though Krishna appears millennium after millennium, material conditioning prevents recognition of His transcendental nature-people see Him through bodily conception, missing His divinity.

questions.prompt: BG 4.7 states that whenever there is decline of what, Krishna appears?
choices: Money and material wealth accumulated in society
Religion and corresponding rise of unrighteousness in the world
Technology and scientific advancement in human civilization
Population and demographic changes across the world
questions.feedback: To establish righteousness and eliminate irreligion, Krishna incarnates.

questions.prompt: How does Krishna's dual purpose in BG 4.8-protecting devotees and destroying demons-reflect divine justice?
choices: The dualist error that good and evil are equally ultimate realities
Mercy to faithful, punishment to wicked upholds cosmic order
The universalist misconception that all receive equal treatment regardless
The impersonalist view that God remains indifferent to moral distinctions
questions.feedback: Divine advent serves both protective mercy (pious) and destructive justice (wicked)-not arbitrary favoritism but upholding dharma by supporting those who serve Him and removing obstacles to righteousness.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.9, what is guaranteed to one who knows the transcendental nature of Krishna's appearance and activities?
choices: Material wealth and worldly prosperity in this lifetime
Liberation and return to His abode after death
Long life primarily through following prescribed scriptural duties
Supernatural powers and mystic siddhis for material benefit
questions.feedback: Understanding Krishna's true nature leads to liberation and return to godhead.

questions.prompt: What does BG 4.10 teach about those who are fully absorbed in Krishna consciousness?
choices: They suffer in the material world due to karmic reactions
They are free from fear, anger, and lust; attain Him
They become weak and unable to function properly in society
They lose interest in life and material responsibilities
questions.feedback: Full surrender to Krishna purifies the heart and grants liberation.

questions.prompt: Why does BG 4.13 organize society by qualities and work rather than birth alone?
choices: The egalitarian misconception that all divisions are oppressive constructs
Natural abilities determine suitable service-proper arrangement
The hereditary corruption that birth determines occupation mechanically
The meritocratic illusion that individual choice alone should determine role
questions.feedback: Varnashrama based on guna (quality) and karma (work) channels natural propensities into social service-not rigid birth-based hierarchy, but recognition that different natures suit different duties in the body politic.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.14, what determines one's work according to the modes of nature?
choices: Family lineage alone passed down through hereditary succession
Quality born of nature (guna) and work performed
Government assignment and social regulations enforced by authorities
Personal preference primarily exercised through free will
questions.feedback: One's own nature and previous karma determine one's fit work.

questions.prompt: BG 4.15 asks: what is the path of those engaged in pure devotional service?
choices: Material success primarily achieved through hard work and effort
Freedom from the result of work in Krsna consciousness
Remaining in the world forever bound by material existence
Achieving great fame through extraordinary accomplishments always
questions.feedback: Devotees are freed from karmic reactions and return to Krishna.

questions.prompt: Why are even the wise bewildered about action and inaction according to BG 4.16?
choices: The phenomenal complexity surpasses human intellectual capacity entirely
Consciousness determines reality-same act binds or liberates
The relativist view that no objective distinction exists between them
Insufficient study prevents understanding this obvious philosophical matter
questions.feedback: Externally identical work can be karma (binding) or akarma (liberating) depending on consciousness-the mystery lies in intention and consciousness, not mechanical performance, bewildering those focused on externals.

questions.prompt: In BG 4.17, what characterizes work performed in knowledge?
choices: It consistently brings material gain and worldly prosperity
It is without attachment, ego, and produces no reaction
It requires great effort through sustained discipline and practice
It brings fear and anxiety about the future results
questions.feedback: Work done selflessly and wisely does not bind one.

questions.prompt: How does BG 4.18's principle of detachment from results free one from karmic reactions?
choices: The stoic suppression of natural desires through willpower alone
Desire for results binds; detachment redirects energy to Krishna
The antinomian error that realized souls can act without consequences
The fatalist resignation that outcomes don't matter since predetermined
questions.feedback: Attachment to fruits entangles consciousness in results, creating karmic bonds; detachment means working for Krishna's satisfaction rather than personal gain-same action performed, different consciousness liberates.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.2, what does Srila Prabhupada warn about regarding Gita commentaries?
choices: All translations of Gita are equally valid spiritually for realization
Demons make good business but don't accept Krsna
Any scholarly interpretation helps spiritual progress and understanding
Personal opinions enhance understanding of scripture's deeper meanings
questions.feedback: The demonic spirit doesn't believe in God but enjoys His property, making business on Krsna's words without accepting Him.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.2, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about the disciplic succession?
choices: Disciplic succession is optional for understanding Gita's teachings
5000 years ago disciplic succession was already broken
Anyone can become spiritual master without succession or qualification
Mundane scholars preserve disciplic succession properly through study
questions.feedback: The Lord detected 5000 years ago that the succession was broken and the Gita's purpose appeared lost.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.10, what false paths does Srila Prabhupada identify?
choices: Devotional service, knowledge, and detachment paths are all false
Attachment to matter, fear of personality, and void conception
Surrender, service, and hearing from spiritual master are misconceptions
Faith, determination, and sense control approaches lead nowhere
questions.feedback: Three false stages: material attachment, fear of spiritual personality, and void conception from frustration.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.10, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about materialistic people and spiritual personality?
choices: Materialists easily accept transcendental personality concept without difficulty
Retaining personality after liberation frightens materialists greatly
Bodily concept helps understand spiritual personality more clearly
Material conception makes spiritual personality attractive and desirable
questions.feedback: Too materially absorbed, the conception of retaining personality after liberation frightens them.

questions.prompt: How does Prabhupada's warning (BG 4.2 purport) about demons making business on Krishna's words apply to modern Gita commentaries that reject Krishna's personality?
choices: The academic pretense of objective scholarship while denying the subject
All interpretations validly contribute to understanding truth equally
Rejecting personal God shows advanced philosophical sophistication
The pluralist view that multiple contradictory readings enrich scripture
questions.feedback: Commentators who profit from Gita's wisdom while denying Krishna's divinity exemplify demonic appropriation: enjoying God's property (spiritual authority, fame, wealth from His words) while refusing to accept the proprietor-like squatters monetizing someone else's house.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.10, what does Srila Prabhupada say about the comparison of living entities to bubbles?
choices: Bubble merging shows perfection of spiritual existence achieved
Merging is fearful stage devoid of perfect knowledge
Ocean bubble analogy proves oneness with Absolute Truth
Individual existence ends at liberation naturally and automatically
questions.feedback: Comparing entities to bubbles merging is a fearful stage of life, devoid of perfect knowledge of spiritual existence.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.34, what false approach does Srila Prabhupada warn against?
choices: Approaching bona fide spiritual master in disciplic succession
Spiritual realization by manufacturing one's own unauthorized process
Following disciplic succession from the Lord Himself directly
Receiving knowledge from self-realized souls in authorized line
questions.feedback: No one can be spiritually realized by manufacturing their own process, as foolish pretenders do.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.34, what does Srila Prabhupada explain about approaching the spiritual master?
choices: Approach with intellectual pride and debate to test teacher
Accept in full surrender and serve like menial servant
Maintain false prestige while taking instruction from guru
Study independently before approaching teacher for confirmation
questions.feedback: Spiritual master should be accepted in full surrender and served like a menial servant, without false prestige.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.34, what does Srila Prabhupada say both blind following and absurd inquiries have in common?
choices: Both are recommended approaches to knowledge
Both lead to spiritual understanding eventually
Both are condemned in this verse
Both demonstrate proper guru-disciple relationship
questions.feedback: In this verse, both blind following and absurd inquiries are condemned.

questions.prompt: How does Prabhupada's instruction (BG 4.34 purport) to approach a guru with surrender, inquiry, and service balance submission with intelligence?
choices: The fundamentalist error of blind acceptance without understanding
Humble service enables receptivity; sincere questions demonstrate seriousness
The skeptic's pride demanding proof before commitment or surrender
The relativist claim that no one has authority to teach absolute truth
questions.feedback: True discipleship avoids both extremes: not blind belief (which lacks understanding) nor prideful interrogation (which lacks humility)-rather, service opens the heart while intelligent inquiry deepens comprehension, uniting devotion and discrimination.

questions.prompt: How does Prabhupada's instruction (BG 4.34 purport) to approach a guru with surrender, inquiry, and service balance submission with intelligence?
choices: The fundamentalist error of blind acceptance without understanding
Humble service enables receptivity; sincere questions demonstrate seriousness
The skeptic's pride demanding proof before commitment or surrender
The relativist claim that no one has authority to teach absolute truth
questions.feedback: True discipleship avoids both extremes: not blind belief (which lacks understanding) nor prideful interrogation (which lacks humility)-rather, service opens the heart while intelligent inquiry deepens comprehension, uniting devotion and discrimination.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 4.34, what is the secret of advancement in spiritual life?
choices: Accumulating theoretical knowledge from books alone suffices
Satisfaction of self-realized spiritual master through service
Independent study and personal interpretation of scriptures
Intellectual debates and philosophical arguments with scholars
questions.feedback: Satisfaction of the self-realized spiritual master is the secret of advancement in spiritual life.
